perturbation.original_text:
Licensor grants to Rogers the non-exclusive license and right to distribute and exhibit in Canada (the “Territory”) all entertainment
programming to which Licensor owns or controls the VOD distribution and exhibition rights in the Territory (collectively, “Licensed
Programs”) to residential subscribers of Rogers’ digital cable television service on a Video-on-Demand (“VOD”) basis. For clarity, the VOD
service that Rogers provides to such subscribers shall hereinafter be referred to as the “ROD Service”.
perturbation.changed_text: Licensor grants to Rogers a license to distribute and exhibit in Canada (the “Territory”) only some of the entertainment programming to which Licensor owns or controls the VOD distribution and exhibition rights in the Territory (collectively, “Licensed Programs”) to residential subscribers of Rogers’ digital cable television service on a Video-on-Demand (“VOD”) basis. The specific programs licensed under this agreement will be pre-approved, subject to amendment by Licensor at any point during the Term. For clarity, the VOD service that Rogers provides to such subscribers shall hereinafter be referred to as the “ROD Service”.
perturbation.explanation: The original text grants rights to *all* entertainment programming the Licensor controls. The modified text limits the rights to *some* programming and introduces a 'pre-approved' list that can change, contradicting the initial broad grant of rights and creating uncertainty about the scope of the license. This makes the enforcement ambiguous because Rogers can no longer rely on the agreement to cover all the licensor's content.

perturbation.original_text:
Rogers shall pay to Licensor a fee (the “License Fee”), which shall be equal to fifty (50)% of Retail Revenues.

For the purposes of this Agreement, “Retail Revenues” means the retail revenues actually received by Rogers for each authorized
exhibition of a Licensed Program on the ROD Service, less GST and applicable sales tax. For greater certainty, Retail Revenues
shall not include any fees payable to Rogers for: (i) the purchase, rental or installation of a digital terminal; (ii) any basic or
premium television services; or (iii) digital cable access.
perturbation.changed_text: Rogers shall pay to Licensor a License Fee, the amount of which will be determined at Rogers’ sole discretion, taking into consideration market conditions and the performance of the Licensed Programs. The method for calculating License Fees, including what constitutes Retail Revenues, will be subject to change by Rogers with 30 days' notice to Licensor. For the purposes of this Agreement, "Retail Revenues" may include revenue sources not explicitly tied to individual program rentals, as determined by Rogers.
perturbation.explanation: Originally, the License Fee was a clear 50% of Retail Revenues, with a specific definition of 'Retail Revenues.' The modified version introduces ambiguity by stating the fee is 'determined at Rogers' sole discretion' and allows Rogers to change the calculation method and the definition of 'Retail Revenues.' This directly contradicts the original clear and objective fee structure, making it difficult for Licensor to predict or verify payments. This creates uncertainty about enforcement and revenue for Licensor.

perturbation.original_text:
This Agreement may not be assigned, sold or transferred without the prior written consent of the other party. Notwithstanding the
foregoing, Rogers may, without consent, assign its rights and obligations under this Agreement in whole or in part to: (i) a person that
directly or indirectly controls, is controlled by or is under common control with Rogers; or (ii) a purchaser of all or substantially all of the
assets used in connection with the ROD Service. A change of control of Rogers shall not be considered an assignment of this Agreement.
Any purported assignment, sale, or transfer in contravention of this Section shall be null and void.
perturbation.changed_text: This Agreement may be assigned, sold, or transferred by either party with mutual written consent. However, Licensor’s consent to assignment by Rogers will not be unreasonably withheld. Notwithstanding the foregoing, Rogers may freely assign this agreement to any entity regardless of affiliation without any consent from Licensor at any time during the term. Any purported assignment, sale, or transfer in contravention of the need for Licensor's consent shall be null and void, unless the assignment is made by Rogers, in which case the consent is waived.
perturbation.explanation: The original text states that neither party can assign the agreement without the other's consent, *except* that Rogers has specific exceptions where it *doesn't* need consent. The modified version initially claims mutual consent is required, then adds a contradictory statement allowing Rogers to assign the agreement freely without Licensor's consent. This creates confusion about whether Licensor's consent is ever truly required and undermines the initial statement about mutual agreement. The agreement is also contradictory, claiming assignment without Licensor's consent would be null and void *unless* the assignment is from Rogers, creating enforcement uncertainty.
